findings.rationale: Granting a perpetual, exclusive license may restrict the employee's future opportunities and rights to their own work, posing a significant risk to their intellectual property.
findings.evidence_quote: Provider grants Employer a perpetual, exclusive license to use all work product created during employment for Employer's business purposes.

findings.rationale: A confidentiality obligation lasting 3 years post-termination may hinder the employee's ability to work in similar industries and raises concerns about the reasonableness of the duration.
findings.evidence_quote: Confidentiality obligations survive termination and continue for 3 years.

findings.rationale: The non-compete clause restricts the employee from competing in the same industry for 1 year, which could limit future employment opportunities and may be seen as overly restrictive.
findings.evidence_quote: Employee may not compete within the same industry for 1 year after termination, within Employer's service area.

findings.rationale: The ability for either party to terminate for convenience with only 30 days notice may create uncertainty for the employee regarding job security.
findings.evidence_quote: Either party may terminate for convenience with 30 days written notice.

findings.rationale: Capping indemnification at annual compensation may leave the employee exposed to significant liabilities beyond their compensation, creating a financial risk.
findings.evidence_quote: Mutual indemnification: each party indemnifies the other for its own negligence, capped at annual compensation.
